description: From Middle English thurghfare, corresponding to thorough- (“through”) +‎ fare. Compare Old English þurhfaran (“to go through, go over, traverse, pierce, pass through, pass beyond, transcend, penetrate”). Compare also Old English þurhfær (“inner secret place”), German Durchfahrt (“passage through, thoroughfare”).

entries.meaning: (now rare except in certain set phrases) A passage; a way through.
A road open at both ends or connecting one area with another; a highway or main street.
examples: Local art is now a viable industry, and hundreds of islanders make a living in it. The thoroughfare of Oneroa village is lined with shops and galleries full of their work.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The act of going through; passage; travel, transit.
examples: The sign leading to the other carriage reads: No thoroughfare.

entries.meaning: An unobstructed waterway allowing passage for ships.
